content.description: Big hands and feet. Depending on just how far right you start, difficulty can be 5.5-5.7. Farther right is easier.
content.location: Located on the uphill side of the boulder. All the way to the right before you turn the corner to the  shelf mantles.

content.description: Start on two crimps and thin feet. Throw up and left to a large diagonal crimp. Go straight up from there.
content.location: Middle of the uphill side of the boulder.

content.description: Climb a series of almost perfect incut crimps up the right side of the boulder. The crimps would be perfect if they weren't a little creaky and flexy. Pull down not out or roll the dice! Fun mantle to top out.
content.protection: A pad is nice but your Santee forefathers did it with a carpet square and they'll tell you all about it.
content.location: Located on the far right of the upper shelf on the north face of the boulder, kinda "pitch 2" of route Flake Left.

content.description: The left facing flake directly in the middle of the face. I started on the bottom of the flake and went directly up. A fun couple of moves to the lip with a satisfying top out.
content.protection: a pad is nice but not necessary
content.location: Located on the shelf on the north side of the boulder. Kinda "pitch 2" of the flake left boulder problem.

content.description: Start on the very left of the shelf. There is a sidepull and an undercling to start with, then move up and feel around for the lip up top. Mantle! Short, but fun. Harder as you go right.
content.protection: Pad, maybe a spotter so you don't fly off the shelf.
content.location: North face of the Lonseome boulder above the shelf.

content.description:
Sit start low on 2 side pulls, make a long reach to the positive part of the arete, and make your way up however you choose.  Here's some beta if you want it

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WqyvelwsvyY

..  I know this boulder has been climbed before but perhaps never in this sequence.  Also, surprisingly, there is no info. even on this boulder's existence here or on any other site I checked.  Soo figured I'd give this baby a name and add a route to it.  I dub this Perry's boulder and it is the small and humble boulder slightly covered by trees and bushes in behind the lonesome boulder.
content.location: Tiny boulder behind the lonesome boulder

content.description: Face climb up to a good hold and follow the big flake/feature up and left.  Fun

content.protection: Gear for TR, or a fairly distant bolt(s)

content.description: Climb up the middle of the tall face using side pulls and a black knob. It would be more classic if it weren't for the dangerously loose flake near the top.
content.protection: Pads, slightly uneven landing. Bolts at top for tr?
content.location: The middle face on the lower half of the lonesome boulder

content.description: Grab the two-handed undercling and work up using sidepulls and crimps. The angle eases up about half way up.
